title: Philosophy and Principles of Palliative Care

sections.content: Philosophy and Principles of Palliative Care
Palliative care is specialized medical care focused on providing relief from symptoms and stress of serious illness, with the goal of improving quality of life for both patients and families.

items: **Whole-Person Care**: Addressing physical, emotional, social, and spiritual needs
**Patient and Family-Centered**: Including family as the unit of care
**Goal-Concordant Care**: Aligning treatments with patient values and preferences
**Comfort Focus**: Optimizing quality of life over quantity

sections.content: Palliative care is an approach that improves the quality of life of patients and their families facing the problems associated with life-threatening illness, through the prevention and relief of suffering by means of early identification and impeccable assessment and treatment of pain and other problems, physical, psychosocial and spiritual.

items:
**Myth**: Palliative care is only for dying patients
**Reality**: Appropriate at any stage of serious illness

**Myth**: Palliative care means giving up hope
**Reality**: Focuses on hope for comfort, meaningful time, quality of life

**Myth**: Palliative care hastens death
**Reality**: Studies show improved survival and quality of life

**Myth**: Pain medications are dangerous
**Reality**: Proper pain management is safe and essential

sections.content: **Best Practice**: Palliative care should be introduced early in the disease trajectory, ideally within 8 weeks of diagnosis of advanced cancer.
